notes.html:p: REFERENCES:Cerveansky and Arias 1984; Barra et al 2003; This study
NOTES:edd encodes the primary enzyme catalyzing this reaction, but sma0235 can partially complement mutations of edd.
REFERENCES:Finan et al 1988; diCenzo and Finan 2015; This study

NOTES:The TnSeq data of this study suggested that gpmA encoded the primary enzyme catalyzing this reaction but that gpmA was likely not absolutely essential. This may be due to partial completemenation by gpmB, and so both genes are included in this reaction.
NOTES:The TnSeq data of this study was consistent with pykA encoding this enzyme, and the ortholog in R. leguminosarum was shown to be a pyruvate kinase (Mulley et al 2010).
NOTES:tpiA mutants could not grow with glycerol or rhamnose, tpiB mutants could not grow with erythritol, and double mutants could not grow with succinate.
NOTES:Each of these genes show similarity to genes encoding fructuse bisphosphate aldolases, however, it has not been experimentially determined which one(s) display this activity in S. meliloti.

NOTES:Experimental data is consistent with cbbF encoding a fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase. However, deletion of this gene does not prevent growth with gluconeogenic substrate suggesting at least one additional copy exists in the genome (diCenzo et al 2016a).

NOTES:Mutation of rpe had no effect in this TnSeq study excet when pSymA and pSymB were removed, suggesting a second copy is encoded on pSymA or pSymB. The most likely candidate is ppe. However, as the rpe mutation in a strain lacking pSymA and pSymB still grows, albiet more slowly, and in silico modelling suggests this is because this reaction is non-essential.

NOTES:This TnSeq data suggested that mutation of tal has major growth phenotype with sucrose when pSymA and pSymB are removed. This provides support for the functional annotation of this gene. It is likely that the phenotype in the pSymA/pSymB cured strain is due to loss of a pathway removing build-up of intermediates instead of the removal of a bypass mechanism. The lack of a phenotype in wild type is likely because this reaction is non-essential, and in silico modelling is consistent with this.

Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex E3 _ Dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase

notes.html:p: REFERENCES:Bielen et al 2014; Soto et al 2001; This study
GENE_ASSOCIATION:(smc02466 and smc02465 and smc02464 and smc02463)
PROTEIN_ASSOCIATION:(SdhB and SdhA and SdhD and SdhC)
REFERENCES:Ramrez-Trujillo et al 2007; Ramrez-Trujillo et al 2016
GENE_ASSOCIATION:(smc00641 or smc04462 or sma1838 or smb20113 or sma0085 or smc02045 or smc02828 or sma0510 or sma1347)
PROTEIN_ASSOCIATION:(SerA or Smc04462 or Sma1838 or Smb20113 or Sma0085 or Smc02045 or Smc02828 or Sma0510 or Sma1347)

NOTES:In this TnSeq data, there were less insertions in serA than expected, consistent with serA encoding the primary enzyme with this function. However, the gene did not appear to be essential, either with and without pSymA and pSymB, indicating that at least one other gene likely is able to at least partially complement serA mutations.
NOTES:Based on Tn-seq and independent mutagenesis and confirmation of auxotrophy (Figure S14).

NOTES:In this TnSeq study, less than expected number of insertions were found in proB1, consistent with this gene encoding the primary enzyme with this activity. However, it did not appear to be essential, likely due to partial complementation by proB2. Indeed, proB2 mutants also had ~ 50% less insertions than expected.
NOTES:The enzyme performing this reaction in S. meliloti has not been identified.
GENE_ASSOCIATION:(smc02138 or smb21186 or smb20277 or smb20379 or smb20973 or smb20423)
PROTEIN_ASSOCIATION:(ArgD or Smb21186 or Smb20277 or Smb20379 or Smb20973 or Smb20423)

NOTES:Mutation of argD prevents growth on minimal media only when pSymB is absent (diCenzo and Finan 2015; This study), consistent with argD having the annotated function and with at least one pSymB encoded protein having the same function
GENE_ASSOCIATION:(sma1836 or smc00682 or smc02256 or smb21279)
PROTEIN_ASSOCIATION:(ArgE or HipO1 or HipO2 or Smb21279)

NOTES:A double argE argJ mutant is not an arginine auxotroph, and each of HipO1, HipO2, and Smb21278 can catalyze this reaction in vitro (Hernndez et al 2015). However, it is not known which gene(s) complement the argJ argE mutant in vivo.

NOTES:This TnSeq data suggested that aatA encodes the primary, if not sole, aspartate aminotransferase involved in aspartate biosynthesis. However, in a different wild type S. meliloti isolate, there appeared to be additional genes able to at least partially complement for mutations of aatA (Rastogi and Watson 1991, Watson and Rastogi 1993)

NOTES:A strain lacking pSymA and pSymB (diCenzo et al 2014), and thus the asnB gene, is not an asparagine auxotroph, indicating either another enzyme encoded by the chromosome that catalyzes this reaction, or asparagine is synthesized by a different pathway in S. meliloti.
REFERENCES:De Bruijn et al 1989; This study

NOTES:This TnSeq data was consistent with dapD encoding the primary enzyme catalyzing this reaction. However, unlike the othe lysine biosynthetic enzymes, dapD mutations did not appear to be absolutely lethal unless pSymA and pSymB were removed. Thus there may be an enzyme encoded by one of these replicons able to slightly complement dapD mutations.
GENE_ASSOCIATION:(smc02138 or smb21186 or smb20277 or smb20379 or smb20973 or smb20423)
PROTEIN_ASSOCIATION:(ArgD or Smb21186 or Smb20277 or Smb20379 or Smb20973 or Smb20423)

NOTES:It was predicted previously (Dunn 2015) that ArgD might perform this function in S. meliloti. However, our data was inconsistent with this hypothesis (Figure S14), and so the gene encoding the enzyme catalyzing this reaction remains unknown.
NOTES:Mutation of neither cysK1 or cysK2 appeared to result in cysteine auxotrophy in this TnSeq data, suggesting both have this activity (and possibly other genes)

NOTES:Based on this TnSeq data, a few insertions within the cysN gene can be isolated and this is mainly dependent on the presence of pSymA and pSymB. Likely, a little bit of activity of the pSymA encoded NodP and NodQ genes (there are two copies of each gene) allow for this.
GENE_ASSOCIATION:(smc02393 or smc00710 or sma0387 or smc03885)
PROTEIN_ASSOCIATION:(HisC4 or HisC1 or HisC3 or HisC2)

NOTES:Based on this TnSeq data, mutation of any of the chromosomal genes does not result in histidine auxotrophy regardless of whether pSymA and pSymB are present. Therefore, it is likely that at least two chromosomal copies are active, if not all four versions of this protein.

NOTES:It was previously noted (Dunn 2015) that rhizobia lack the classical enzyme catalyzing this reaction and that the HisB ezymes of rhizobia are unlikely to be bifunctional and also perform this role. Instead, it was hypothesized that an inositol monophosphatase family protein could fulfil this function (Dunn 2015). As Smc04042 is an inositol monophosphatase family protein that was essential in this Tn-seq work, and its mutation results in histidine auxotrophy (Figure S14), we suggest that Smc04042 (and its orthologs) fulfills this role.
GENE_ASSOCIATION:(smc02393 or smc00710 or sma0387 or smc03885)
PROTEIN_ASSOCIATION:(HisC4 or HisC1 or HisC3 or HisC2)

NOTES:Based on this TnSeq data, mutation of any of the chromosomal genes does not result in auxotrophy regardless of whether pSymA and pSymB are present. Therefore, it is likely that at least two chromosomal copies are active, if not all four versions of this protein.
GENE_ASSOCIATION:(smc04326 or smc01578 or smc00294 or smc00387 or smc02262 or smb20039 or smc01969 or smc04386 or smc03885 or smc02393 or smc00710 or sma0387)
PROTEIN_ASSOCIATION:(Smc04326 or AatA or Smc00294 or TatA or Smc02262 or Smb20039 or Smc01969 or AatB or HisC2 or HisC4 or HisC1 or HisC3)

NOTES:No mutation of any one of the listed genes appeared to result in tyrosine auxotrophy in this TnSeq data, suggesting that at least two enzymes must have this function. While aatA mutations did appear to result in auxotrophy, this was likely due to AatA being involved in asparate biosynthesis.
GENE_ASSOCIATION:(smc04326 or smc01578 or smc00294 or smc00387 or smc02262 or smb20039 or smc01969 or smc04386)
PROTEIN_ASSOCIATION:(Smc04326 or AatA or Smc00294 or TatA or Smc02262 or Smb20039 or Smc01969 or AatB)

NOTES:No mutation of any one of the listed genes appeared to result in tyrosine auxotrophy in this TnSeq data, suggesting that at least two enzymes must have this function. While aatA mutations did appear to result in auxotrophy, this was likely due to AatA being involved in asparate biosynthesis.

NOTES:Mutation of ald did not appear to result in alanine auxotrophy in this TnSeq data. This suggests that either an alternate alanine dehydrogenase exists, or L-alanine is produce through an alternate route. Therefore, Unknowns have been included with this reaction, and an alternate pathway through D-alanine has also been added (see rxns rnx00849 and rxn00283).
NOTES:ilvA did not appear to be essential for branched chain amino acid metabolism in this TnSeq data, which may be due to a bypass through rxn02302
REFERENCES:de las Nieves Peltzer et al 2008; This study

NOTES:The IlvH protein is not-essential for this reaction (not due to redundancy, but simply because the protein is non-essential), but the reaction is essential for branched chain amino acid biosynthesis. Therefore the 'or NonEssential' was added to represent this and allow the reaction to proceed when ilvH is deleted in silico.
REFERENCES:de las Nieves Peltzer et al 2008; This study
NOTES:The evidence from this study includes both Tn-seq and independent mutagenesis and confirmation of auxotrophy.
REFERENCES:de las Nieves Peltzer et al 2008; This study
NOTES:The evidence from this study includes both Tn-seq and independent mutagenesis and confirmation of auxotrophy.
REFERENCES:de las Nieves Peltzer et al 2008; This study
NOTES:Mutants of either just ilvE2 or ilvE1 are prototrophs (de las Nieves Peltzer et al 2008), and so both may catalyze this reaction.
REFERENCES:de las Nieves Peltzer et al 2008; This study

NOTES:The IlvH protein is not-essential for this reaction (not due to redundancy, but simply because the protein is non-essential), but the reaction is essential for branched chain amino acid biosynthesis. Therefore the 'or NonEssential' was added to represent this and allow the reaction to proceed when IlvH is deleted in silico.

NOTES:Mutants of either just ilvE2 or ilvE1 are prototrophs (de las Nieves Peltzer et al 2008), and so both may catalyze this reaction

NOTES:S. meliloti 1021 appears to lack an asparaginyl-tRNA synthetase, and so the synthesis of asparaginyl-tRNA may proceed via an aspartate---tRNAAsn ligase. The enzyme that catalyzes this reaction in S. meliloti has not been examined, but as some AspS proteins can catalyze this reaction, this may be the case in S. meliloti.
NOTES:The gatA gatB and gatC genes appeared essential in this TnSeq data. However, whether this is due to its role in this reaction, rxn10534, or both is not known.\
NOTES:The gatA gatB and gatC genes appeared essential in this TnSeq data. However, whether this is due to its role in this reaction, rxn10534, or both is not known.\

reaction.name: Ribosome biogenesis, tRNA modification, protein translation

notes.html:p: GENE_ASSOCIATION:(smc00323 and smc00335 and smc00363 and smc00364 and smc01152 and smc04434 and (smc00565 or NonEssential) and smc00567 and smc00568 and smc01803 and smc01804 and smc01369 and smc01321 and smc01320 and smc01319 and smc01318 and smc01314 and smc01313 and smc01310 and smc01309 and smc01308 and smc01307 and smc01306 and smc01305 and smc01304 and smc01303 and smc01302 and smc01301 and smc01300 and smc01299 and smc01298 and smc01297 and smc01296 and smc01295 and smc01294 and smc01293 and smc01292 and smc01291 and smc01290 and smc01287 and smc01286 and smc01283 and smc02101 and smc00485 and smc03934 and smc02692 and smc00704 and smc03990 and smc04003 and smc03770 and smc03772 and smc03859 and smc03863 and smc03881 and smb20995 and smc01722 and smc02651 and smc02098 and smc02310 and smc02914 and smc00362 and smc02436 and smc02100 and smc01312 and (smc01311 or smc01326) and smc02405 and (smc00579 or NonEssential) and (smc00357 or NonEssential) and (smc00349 or NonEssential) and smc01720 and smc03861 and smc02652 and smc03860 and smc01333 and smc00427 and smc03775)

PROTEIN_ASSOCIATION:(RpsO and RpsA and RpmI and RplT and RpsT and RpmH and (RplI or NonEssential) and RpsR and RpsF and RpsI and RplM and RpmG and RplK and RplA and RplJ and RplL and RpsL and RpsG and RpsJ and RplC and RplD and RplW and RplB and RpsS and RplV and RpsC and RplP and RpmC and RpsQ and RplN and RplX and RplE and RpsN and RpsH and RplF and RplR and RpsE and RpmD and RplO and RpsM and RpsK and RplQ and RpsB and RpsD and RpsU2 and RplY and RpmB and RpmE and RpmJ and RplU and RpmA and RpsP and and RplS and RpmF and EngA and EngB and Era and Rrf and InfA and InfB and InfC and PrfA and Tsf and FusA1 and (TufA or TufB) and SmpB and (KsgA or NonEssential) and (Efp or NonEssential) and (LepA or NonEssential) and RnpA and TrmD and Rnc and RimM and PrfB and PfrC and ObgE)

NOTES:All genes considered essential in this annotation are supported as essential in the TnSeq data, supporting their annotation. However, those marked as non-essential require further study to confirm their function. Less insertions than expected were found in rplI, consistent with its annotated function, although not definitive. Less insertions than expected were found in both tufA and tufB, consistent with both having the annotated function but neither being sufficient to fully complement the other and that mutation of both may be required to result in a loss of this activity. Less than expected number of insertions were also found in efp, consistent with its annotation.

NOTES:The map1 gene appeared essential in this TnSeq data only in the absence of pSymA and pSymB. This is consistent with map1 having the annotated function but with a second copy on pSymA or pSymB, the most likely candidate being map2. Interestingly, map2 is on pSymB due to a translocation from the chromosome (diCenzo et al 2013)

NOTES:In this TnSeq data, it appeared that purN mutations were not lethal except in the absence of pSymA and pSymB. In E. coli, FGAT can be produced by PurN or by PurU/PurT. We therefore suggest that the PurU protein encoded on pSymA together with an unidentified PurT homolog can bypass PurN in S. meliloti.
REFERENCES:Taga and Walker 2010; Cowie et al 2006; This study
REFERENCES:Taga and Walker 2010; Cowie et al 2006; This study
REFERENCES:Kerppola and Kahn 1988a; Vineetha et al 2001; This study

NOTES:In some organisms like Pseudomonas putida, the PyrB protein requires an inactive dihydroorotase protein to function. The Smc01361 protein is encoded downstream of the PyrB protein, is annotated as a dihydroorotase, was essential in this Tn-seq study, and its mutation results in pyrimidine auxotrophy as determined in this study (Figure S14). We therefore postulate that Smc01361 is an inactive dihydroorotase required for PyrB function.
REFERENCES:Taga and Walker 2010; Cowie et al 2006; This study
REFERENCES:Ross et al 1990; O'Flaherty et al 1995; This study

NOTES:This gene did not appear essential in this TnSeq data, although less than expected number of insertions were found in this gene during growth in rich medium. The inclusion of this reaction is not due to a requirement to produce CMP, but due to a requirement to metabolize CMP released during other reactions. This reaction is presumably dispensible in true cells due to other fates of the CMP.

GENE_ASSOCIATION:((smc02789 or NonEssential) and smc01375 and smc02905 and smc01190 and smc00415 and smc00586 and smc02802 and smc00561 and smc01567 and smc02857 and smc01142 and smc01233 and (smc00018 or smc02327 or smc00867) and (smc02850 or NonEssential) and smc01878 and smc01231 and smc02782 and smc01761 and smc01018 and smc01364 and smc00617 and smc01167 and smc02496 and smc02800 and smc02801)

PROTEIN_ASSOCIATION:((DnaQ or NonEssential) and DnaE1 and DnaX and Smc01190 and DnaN and Smc00586 and Smc02802 and DnaB and DnaG and DnaK and GrpE and Ssb and (RnhA or RnhA2 or RnhB) and (PolA or NonEssential) and LigA and GyrA and GyrB and ParC and ParE and TopA and Smc00617 and DnaA and PriA and ParA and ParB)
REFERENCES:Margolin et al 1995; Nisa-Martnez et al 2016; Frage et al 2016; Cowie et al 2006; This study

NOTES:The annotation of many of the proteins are supported by previous work and their mutation appeared lethal in this TnSeq data. However, the role of proteins that either appear non-essential or redundant are not validated. The Smc00617 protein is included here as it was essential in the TnSeq data and may be an ortholog of the essential Hda protein of E. coli. There appears to be no theta or psi polymerase subunits in S. meliloti, which both are non-essential in E. coli. DnaQ also appeared non-essential, although this may simply be due to compensatory mutations.
GENE_ASSOCIATION:(smc01285 and smc01317 and smc01316 and smc02408 and smc01563 and (smc01218 or sma0149) and smc02912 and smc01778 and smc01322 and smc02796 and smc02700)
PROTEIN_ASSOCIATION:(RpoA and RpoB and RpoC and RpoZ and RpoD and (GreA or Sma0149) and NusA and NusB and NusG and Rho and Smc02700)
REFERENCES:Neilson and Brown 1985; Peck et al 2002; Wells and Long 2003; Rushing and Long 1995; Cowie et al 2006; This study

NOTES:In this TnSeq data, greA was only essential in the absence of pSymA and pSymB, suggesting both that the product of greA has the annotated function and that there is a second copy on pSymA or pSymB, with the most likey candidate being sma0149.
REFERENCES:Nogales et al 2010; Cowie et al 2006; This study
REFERENCES:Platt et al 1990; Lpez-Lara and Geiger 2000; This study

NOTES:In this TnSeq data, fabD did not appear to be absolutely essential, particularly in strains lacking pSymA and pSymB. There may therefore be another enzyme encoded by the S. meliloti chromosome capable of performing this reaction, but at a slow rate. A possible candidate is RkpA.
NOTES:Only FabZ was added to this reaction based on the differences in affinities for the substrate of the E. coli proteins (Heath and Rock 1996), but FabA may also catalyze this reaction

NOTES:There are two fabI genes in S. meliloti, and in this TnSeq data, both appeared essential suggesting they likely have separate functions. As fabI2 is located next to fabB and fabA, we predict that FabI2 functions as the general enzyme associated with this reaction, while FabI1 is involved in very long chain fatty acid biosynthesis.

NOTES:FabF and FabB are annotated as catalyzing the same reaction, but both were essential in this TnSeq data. Therefore they presumably have distinct, but likely overlapping, substrate specificity. Therefore, in most cases the reactions are annotated as FabF or FabB since it has not been studies in S. meliloti the substrate specificies of these enzymes. There are only two reactions where we have put just FabF just FabB, and these are based on the substrate specificities of these enzymes in E. coli (Feng and Cronan 1990, Garwin et al 1980)

NOTES:Both FabZ and FabA were added to this reaction based on the differences in affinities for the substrate of the E. coli proteins (Heath and Rock 1996), but this may not be the case in S. meliloti.

As fabI2 is located next to fabB and fabA, we predict that FabI2 functions as the general enzyme associated with this reaction, while FabI1 is involved in very long chain fatty acid biosynthesis.

NOTES:FabF and FabB are annotated as catalyzing the same reaction, but both were essential in this TnSeq data. Therefore they presumably have distinct, but likely overlapping, substrate specificity. Therefore, in most cases the reactions are annotated as FabF or FabB since it has not been studies in S. meliloti the substrate specificies of these enzymes. There are only two reactions where we have put just FabF just FabB, and these are based on the substrate specificities of these enzymes in E. coli (Feng and Cronan 1990, Garwin et al 1980)

NOTES:In this TnSeq data, fabD did not appear to be absolutely essential, particularly in strains lacking pSymA and pSymB. There may therefore be another enzyme encoded by the S. meliloti chromosome capable of performing this reaction, but at a slow rate. A possible candidate is RkpA.

NOTES:Both of these proteins are expected to have the same protein function, yet both appear essential for VLCA biosynthesis. It is therefore likely that they have different substrate affinities. However, as this has not been studied, both proteins have been added to all reactions and an 'AND' statement used, even though it is likely that both are not required for each reaction

NOTES:Smc04277 appears quite important for VLCA biosynthesis but is not absolutely essential. It was suggested that this is due to some complementation by FabZ (Haag et al 2011), but has not been experimentally tested.

NOTES:In this TnSeq data, gpsA appeared essential only when pSymA and pSymB was absent. This is consistent both the GpsA having the annotated function, and with a pSymA or pSymB encoded bypass mechanism. A candidate is Smb20499, which is included in this reaction. However, the Smb20499 protein is annotated as using FAD (not NADP) as a co-factor. But when Smb20499 was included in this core model with a FAD co-factor, the TCA cycle was rendered non-essential, and so we have for now left this enzyme here with a NADP co-factor, although this may need to be corrected.

NOTES:The smc01362 gene is annotated as encoding a hypothetical transmembrane protein. However, its product shows similarity to PlsY proteins and it appeared essential in this TnSeq data. Therefore, we have annotated this gene as plsY.

NOTES:Mutations of plsC result in a slow growth phenotype with some cell lysis in liquid cultures (Basconcillo et al 2009). However, in this TnSeq data, mutations of plsC appeared less severe in the strain lacking pSymA and pSymB, likely because these strains already show a slow growth phenotype.

NOTES:The enzyme catalyzing this reaction has not been identified in S. meliloti. Smc04406 shows some similarity to these enzymes and is therefore a candidate, but this has not been tested. Additionally, its deletion does not appear lethal (TnSeq), suggesting another enzyme has this activity as well (or in place of).

NOTES:Previous work (Basconcillo et al 2009) indicated that a plsC mutant did not impair the addition of C18 fatty acids, suggesting another enzyme(s) must fulfill this reaction. The indicated enzymes are possible candidates, and PlsC could also potentially play a role as well.

NOTES:A reaction to combine the different PGs in the correct ratio (Basconcillo et al 2009b).

NOTES:Cls appears to be the only cardiolipin synthase in the S. meliloti genome based on sequence similarity. However, its activity in S. meliloti has not been confirmed, although the Cls in Rhizobium etli has been (Sandoval-Caldern et al 2009), and it has not been confirmed to be the only enzyme capable of performing this reaction (only Cls has this activity in R. etli). smc02076 appeared non-essential based on this TnSeq data, but this is likely just becuase cardiolipin biosynthesis could be dispensable.

NOTES:This reaction has been included here as the synthesis of cardiolipid is associated with the release of a glycerol molecule, and this must be removed for the model to function. However, GlpK is not normally essential, presumably as the glycerol can be exported instead or metabolized through other pathways.

NOTES:A reaction to combine the different CLs in the desired ratio. The ratio of CLs in S. meliloti has not been reported. But as CLs are formed by the condensation of two PG molecules, we used the same ratio as that reported for PGs as an approximation (Basconcillo et al 2009b).

NOTES:A reaction to combine the different PEs in the desired ratio. As the ratio of PEs in S. meliloti has not been studied, the ratio was approximated by using the same as the ratio of PCs as PEs are a substrate for the synthesis of PCs (Basconcillo et al 2009b).

NOTES:A reaction to combine the different PCs in the correct ratio (Basconcillo et al 2009b).
NOTES:Experimental data is consistent with DgkA having the annotated function. However, it is not know whether this is the only enzyme in the S. meliloti proteome capable of performing this reaction.
NOTES:Prediction is based on sequence similarity and proximity to the SqdB gene known to be involved in sulfolipid biosynthesis (Weissenmayer et al 2000)

NOTES:Experimental data is consistent with DgkA catalyzing the annotated function. However, it is not know whether this is the only enzyme in the S. meliloti proteome capable of performing this reaction.

NOTES:A reaction to combine the different SLs in the correct ratio (Basconcillo et al 2009b).
NOTES:A reaction to combine the different OLs in the correct ratio (Basconcillo et al 2009b).

NOTES:In this TnSeq data, glmS was only essential in the absence of pSymA and pSymB. This is consistent with GlmS having the annotated function and with a second copy encoded on pSymA or pSymB, which is presumably NodM as this protein has been experimentally shown to have this function.

NOTES:This TnSeq data was consistent with MurE having the annotated function. However, it appeared as though mutations of murE were not absolutely lethal, suggesting there may be a low rate of bypass of this enzyme possibly as a non-specific activity of another protein.

NOTES:The gene smc02090 was annotated as a conserved hypothetical protein, but is located in a locus containing lipopolysaccharide bioxynthetic genes. It also appeared essential in this TnSeq data. Therefore we have reannotated this gene as lpxI, whose product replaces the function of the LpxH protein of E. coli based on previous work with C. crescentus (Metzger and Raetz 2010).
REFERENCES:Clover et al 1989; Lagares et al 1992; Niehaus et al 1998; Lagares et al 2001; Campbell et al 2002; Campbell et al 2003; Kanipes et al 2003; This study

NOTES:The structure of the core oligosaccharide of S. meliloti does not appear to have been characterized, but its composition has been (Campbell et al 2002). However, there is evidence that the first sugar added is a glucose (Kanipes et al 2003) and that this is mediated by LpsB. Therefore, there is one reaction adding glucose, and then another reaction that adds all the other sugars in the determined ratio. Interestingly, this TnSeq data suggested the relative importance of the different sugar transferases might be influenced by the medium; for example, lpsB appeared to become dispensible in the defined medium in wild type, wehreas lpsC appeared to become more important.
NOTES:As we were unsure how to synthesize this compound present in the core oligosaccharide, we have added it as a demand compound.

reaction.name: Addition of the rest of the core oligosaccharide to lipid A

notes.html:p: GENE_ASSOCIATION:(smc01222 and smc01221 and smc01220 and smc01219)
PROTEIN_ASSOCIATION:(LpsC and LpsD and LpsE and LpsB)
REFERENCES:Clover et al 1989; Lagares et al 1992; Niehaus et al 1998; Lagares et al 2001; Campbell et al 2002; Campbell et al 2003; Kanipes et al 2003; This study

NOTES:The structure of the core oligosaccharide of S. meliloti does not appear to have been characterized, but its composition has been (Campbell et al 2002). However, there is evidence that the first sugar added is a glucose (Kanipes et al 2003) and that this is mediated by LpsB. Therefore, there is one reaction adding glucose, and then another reaction that adds all the other sugars in the determined ratio. Interestingly, this TnSeq data suggested the relative importance of the different sugar transferases might be influenced by the medium; for example, lpsB appeared to become dispensible in the defined medium in wild type, wehreas lpsC appeared to become more important.

reaction.name: Addition of the O-antigen to LPS

notes.html:p: NOTES:To the best of our knowledge, the genetics of O-antigen bisynthesis in S. meliloti has not been studied. Indeed, Sharypova et al (2003) stated "Consequently, not a single gene was assigned to a function in O antigen biosynthesis." Therefore, an unknown has been added for this reaction.
REFERENCES:Reuber and Walker 1993; Mller et al 1993
REFERENCES:Reuber and Walker 1993; Long et al 1988; Becker et al 1993b; Finan et al 1985; Leigh et al 1985

NOTES:The chromosomal exoN2 gene was only essential in this TnSeq study when pSymA and pSymB were absent. This is consistent with ExoN2 having the annotated function, and with a second copy on pSymA or pSymB. This would be the exoN gene, which has some experimental evidence for its activity (Becker et al 1993b)
NOTES:Uxs was experimentally shown to have this activity. However, it was not tested if this I the only enzyme in S. meliloti to have this function.

NOTES:In this TnSeq data, kpsF3 was only essential when pSymA and pSymB was removed. This is consistent with KpsF3 having the annotated function, with at least one additional copy encoded by pSymA or pSymB, with KpsF2 and KpsF1 being the best candidates.

NOTES:The enzyme catalyzing this reaction has not been identified in S. meliloti. We have put Smc01026 here as a prediction based on co-occurance with the kdsA gene in S. meliloti (likely an operon) and in other organisms (see the STRING database). However, the gene did not appear to be essential in this TnSeq data, and thus if this protein does have this function, there must be another protein able to complement its loss.

NOTES:The genes encoding the enzymes involved in the beta-alanine biosynthetic pathway represented by rxn07111, rxn0720, rxn01626, and rxn00654 appeared non-essential in this TnSeq data. Therefore, it is likely that an alternative pathway for the synthesis of beta-alanine exists in S. meliloti; however, what this pathway is remains unclear. However, as at least some rhizobial species can produce low amounts of beta-alanine through aspartate decarboxylation (Billen and Lichstein 1949), we have added such a reaction (rxn00346) with an unknown GPR in order to force the current pathway to be non-essential.

NOTES:We named these enzymes as PreT and PreA based on homology to the E. coli PreT and PreA proteins. NOTES:In some organisms, like C. glutamicum (Merkamm et al 2003), this reaction is only catalyzed by IlvC. As there does not appear to be a PanE enzyme encoded by S. meliloti, we predicted IlvC has this activity in S. meliloti. However, our data is unconsistent with this hypothesis (Figure S14), and therefore the gene encoding the enzyme catalyzing this reaction remains unknown.

NOTES:pabB did not appear essential inthis TnSeq study, suggesting that if PabB catalyzes this reaction, there must be a bypass or another ezyme capable of complementing for its loss. One possibility would be TrpE. Additionally, generally this reaction would involve L-glutamate and have two subunits, PabB and PabA. However, no pabA gene was found in the genome. As PabA is not essential when there is exogenous ammonia, this reaction was prepared without PabA and with ammonia instead of glutamate.

NOTES:The gene smc04014 was annotated as a hypothetical protein in the genome. However, given it is adjacent to pabB and its product has (weak) similarity to PabC enzymes, we predict this gene encodes a PabC enzyme and have annotated it as such. However, smc04014 did not appear essential in this TnSeq data, suggesting that if if PabC catalyzes this reaction, there must be a bypass or another ezyme capable of complementing for its loss. One possibility would be TrpG.

NOTES:The ezyme(s) catalyzing this reaction has not been examined in S. meliloti. The Smc01907 and Smc03108 were taken from the Kbase automated S. meliloti metabolic reconstruction, and Smc03243 is from KEGG. Which, if any of these, perform this reaction requires further study.
NOTES:Fhs did not appear essential in this TnSeq data, likely because this reaction can be bypassed through a few other metabolic reactions.

NOTES:In this TnSeq data, it appeared that folD2 was essential for growth in the wild type background, suggesting the product of folD1 has little role in this reaction in the wild type in these conditions. However, in the strain lacking pSymA and pSymB, folD2 appeared largely dispensable. This may suggest that at least under certain conditions, the product of folD1 can compensate for the loss of folD2, and therefore both have been included with this reaction.

NOTES:In this TnSeq data, it appeared that folD2 was essential for growth in the wild type background, suggesting the product of folD1 has little role in this reaction in the wild type in these conditions. This may suggest that at least under certain conditions, the product of folD1 can compensate for the loss of folD2, and therefore both have been included with this reaction.
NOTES:This reaction was added to remove the glycolaldehyde product of the rxn02504 reaction. An anzyme performing this reaction in S. meliloti has not been identified to our knowledge.

NOTES:This reaction was added to remove the glycolaldehyde product of the rxn02504 reaction. None of these genes appeared essential in this TnSeq data, likely due to other fates of the glycolate/glycolaldehyde, such as excretion.

PROTEIN_ASSOCIATION:(NifS and Unknown and ThiS and ThiG)

NOTES:The ThiG protein forms the product of this reaction by combining the products of the ThiO and Dxs reactions above with a sulfur atom from cysteine which is transferred through a system possibly involving NifS, a protein not yet identified in S. meliloti (ThiI in E. coli) and ThiS. The inclusion of thiamine in the medium during this TnSeq study meant that this reaction was non-essential.

NOTES:Experimental evidence is consistent with ThiE catalyzing this reaction, but it has not been examined whether ThiE2 can also perform this reaction. In B. subtilis, the TenI protein first converts the substrate of the cpd02654 substrate of this reaction to a different metabolite, which is then used by ThiE (Hazra et al 2011), but ThiE can also usethe cpd02654 substrate in vitro. As we did not detect a TenI ortholog in S. meliloti, we have set ThiE to use the cpd02654 metabolite although this may not be correct. The inclusion of thiamine in the medium during this TnSeq study meant that this reaction was non-essential.

NOTES:The smc03995 gene appeared essential in this TnSeq data. As this gene appears to be part of an operon with thiE2 (involved in the previous reaction in thiamine biosynthesis), and as the protein catalyzing the current reaction has not been identified, we predict that Smc03995 may fulfill this function. However, this may be incorrect, particularly as thiamine was included in the medium, which we expect should have rendered this reaction non-essential (and thus smc03995 still being essential may suggest it plays a different fuction).
REFERENCES:Yang et al 2002; Yurgel et al 2014

NOTES:Experimental evidence is consistent with RibBA performing this reaction (Yang et al 2002, Yurgel et al 2014). However, there appears to be another enzyme capable of complementing for the deletion of ribBA as such a mutant is not a riboflavin auxotroph (Yurgel et al 2014).
NOTES:The enzyme performing this reaction in S. meliloti has not been identified to the best of our knowledge
REFERENCES:Yang et al 2002; Yurgel et al 2014

NOTES:Experimental evidence is consistent with RibBA performing this reaction (Yang et al 2002, Yurgel et al 2014). However,there appears to be another enzyme capable of complementing for the deletion of ribBA as such a mutant is not a riboflavin auxotroph (Yurgel et al 2014).
NOTES:Neither RibH1 or RibH2 appeared essential for riboflavin biosynthesis in this TnSeq data, and so it is likely both are functional.

NOTES:The ribE gene appear non-essential unless pSymA and pSymB were absent in this TnSeq study. This is both consistent with RibE having the annotated function, and with an unidentified enzyme on pSymA or pSymB possibly bypassing the need for RibE.
NOTES:Based on this TnSeq data, hemB mutations had a growth defect, consistent with its annotated function, but hemB appeared non-essential suggesting a slow rate of bypass by another enzyme
NOTES:This enzyme has not been identified in S. meliloti to the best of our knowledge
NOTES:In this TnSeq data, mutation of ctaA appeared to result in very slow growth but appeared non essential, possibly suggesting Heme O is not absolutely essential for growth.
NOTES:In this TnSeq data, mutation of ctaA appeared to result in slow growth but appeared non essential, possibly suggesting Heme A is not absolutely essential for growth.

NOTES:This is not an essential reaction since other enzymes can reduce FMN, but this one was included to ensure sufficient flux without disturbing other reactions, and KEGG includes this enzyme as catalyzing this reaction.
REFERENCES:Campbell et al 2006; Taga et al 2007

NOTES:While bluB has previously been shown to be essential for this reaction, we note that bluB did not appear to be essential in this TnSeq data in either strain - perhaps the product of the reaction is excreted by the bluB+ cells of the population, thereby complementing the bluB- phenotype of the small percentage of the population that would have been bluB mutants.

NOTES:The function of this gene is predicted based on homology. It did not appear essential in this TnSeq data. This was included to remove the accumulation of niacin from the rx02897 reaction, and PncB is therefore likely non-essential due to other fates of the niacin when this reaction is blocked. A NonEssential gene has been added so that PncB is not essential in silico.
NOTES:It is unclear what enzyme performs this reaction in S. meliloti to the best of our knowledge.

NOTES:All three of the indicated proteins could potentially have this function. Based on this TnSeq data, mutations of cobA have the greatest effect on growth, suggesting that CobA is the primary enzyme responsible for this reaction.

PROTEIN_ASSOCIATION:(CobN and CobS and CobT and CobW)

NOTES:Each of cobN, cobS, and cobT appeared essential in this TnSeq data, consistent with their function. Few insertions were found in cobW in wild type, and none were found in the absence of pSymA and pSymB, consistent with an important function of CobW in cobalamin biosynthesis. However, the role of this protein is not known. It is often found downstream of CobN and may play a role in loading of the cobalt into the molecule. Therefore, CobW has been included in this step of the model, but this may be an error.
NOTES:It is unclear what enzyme performs this reaction in S. meliloti.

NOTES:In this TnSeq data, cobO appeared to be essential. Another putative CobO is encoded by smc00731; however, both genes are also present in S. fredii NGR234, and mutation of just the smc04302 ortholog, but not the smc00731 (the second putative cobO) ortholog, resulted in cobalamin auxotrophy (Medina et al 2009).
NOTES:The ispA gene appeared non-essential in this TnSeq study, suggesting that if IspA has the annotated function, a bypass is encoded elsewhere on the chromosome.
NOTES:The ispA gene appeared non-essential in this TnSeq study, suggesting that if IspA has the annotated function, a bypass is encoded elsewhere on the chromosome.

NOTES:The enzyme catalyzing this reaction in S. meliloti is not known. The indicated protein is one possible candidate, but even if this protein has this activity, there must be at least one additional copy on the chromosome otherwise strains lacking pSymB would not grow on minimal medium, which they do.

NOTES:Based on this TnSeq study, ubiB appears to be an essential gene and is therefore likely involved in this reaction as expected. However, UbiB orthologs are expected not to directly catalyze this reaction but to instead be a kinase regulator of the UbiI protein that performs this reaction. As this enzyme is not identified in S. meliloti, an UnknownC has been added.

NOTES:S. meliloti encodes two proteins that show homology to UbiH proteins, which are encoded by smc03804 and smc00316, but no apparent UbiF ortholog. UbiH and UbiF proteins are similar to each other. We therefore suggest that one of the UbiH orthologs in S. meliloti functions as UbiH and the other as UbiF. We have annotated the protein encoded by smc03804 as UbiH as it shows more similarity to this protein class, and the protein encoded by smc00316 as UbiF. Also, mutations of the ubiH gene appeared to have a large fitness cost in wild type S. meliloti strain in this TnSeq study, but did not appear essential in the absence of pSymA and pSymB. It is unclear why this is.
NOTES:The ubiE gene appeared essential in a wild type S. meliloti strain in a this TnSeq study, but did not appear essential in the absence of pSymA and pSymB. It is unclear why this is.

NOTES:S. meliloti encodes two proteins that show homology to UbiH proteins, which are encoded by smc03804 and smc00316, but no apparent UbiF ortholog. UbiH and UbiF proteins are similar to each other. We therefore suggest that one of the UbiH orthologs in S. meliloti functions as UbiH and the other as UbiF. We have annotated the protein encoded by smc03804 as UbiH as it shows more similarity to this protein class, and the protein encoded by smc00316 as UbiF. Also, the smc00316 gene appeared essential in this TnSeq study.

NOTES:The SerC enzyme is involved in both serine and pyridoxal biosynthesis in E. coli; however, our data was inconsistent with this dual function of SerC in S. meliloti (Figure S14). It therefore remains unclear which gene encodes the enzyme responsible for this reaction.

NOTES:In this TnSeq study, insertions within ppk were readily obtained in the wild type strain but few insertions were found in a strain lacking pSymA or pSymB. This is consistent with polyphosphate synthesis being a core aspect of S. meliloti metabolism, and that at least one additional polyphosphate kinase exists on pSymA or pSymB, the most likely being the two listed genes.

NOTES:One study presented experimental evidence that mutation of the chromosomal gshB1 gene prevented glutathionine biosynthesis, consistent with GshB1 being the only functional protein. However, in this TnSeq study, gshB1 only appeared to be an essential protein in the absence of pSymA and pSymB, consistent with GshB1 and GshB2 both having this activity.
NOTES:While experimental evidence has shown all of these proteins to have catalase activity, it has not been demonstrated that these are the only catalases in the proteome.
